diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints, leading to pain, swelling (synovitis), and potential joint destruction (arthropathy). Systemic features can include pleural effusion and skin manifestations like rheumatoid nodules, but follicular hyperkeratosis is not typically associated.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including joints (arthropathy, synovitis), skin (follicular hyperkeratosis), and serous membranes leading to pleural effusion. Diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical signs and specific antibodies.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. It can cause synovitis and arthropathy in affected joints. Skin lesions of psoriasis often include plaques with scales, which can be considered a form of hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A multisystem inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas in various organs. It can cause arthropathy and skin manifestations, such as plaques and nodules (which could include follicular hyperkeratosis), and it may lead to pleural effusion if the lungs are involved.

diagnoses.name: Osteoarthritis
diagnoses.description: A degenerative joint disease that leads to the breakdown of cartilage and bone. While primarily characterized by arthropathy, it does not typically present with synovitis, pleural effusion, or follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Gout
diagnoses.description: A form of inflammatory arthritis characterized by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood, leading to the formation of urate crystals in joints (causing arthropathy and synovitis). Though traditionally not associated with pleural effusion or follicular hyperkeratosis, it presents with distinct tophaceous deposits.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis
diagnoses.description: An umbrella term for several types of arthritis affecting children under 16, featuring prolonged joint inflammation (synovitis) and arthropathy. Some forms may have systemic features but rarely include pleural effusion or follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. Although primarily affecting muscles and skin, it can lead to arthropathy. The association with pleural effusion is rare, and while skin manifestations are present, they don't typically include follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, transmitted by ticks. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including arthropathy and rarely, pleural effusion. Skin manifestations are common but typically are erythematous rashes rather than follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that cause hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can affect the joints (arthropathy), and in systemic sclerosis, it might lead to pleural effusion. Specific skin changes include tight, thickened skin rather than follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses: Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) with a possible autoimmune component
Schizophrenia (in the context of autoimmune encephalitis)
Psychotic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Poor healing and atherosclerosis are common complications. In severely uncontrolled cases, peripheral neuropathy and vascular disease can lead to ulcers.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: Can present with poor healing, lymphadenopathy, ulcers, and increased susceptibility to infections like laryngitis.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reasoning: A group of disorders causing inflammation of blood vessels, which can lead to atherosclerosis, poor healing, and ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Lymphadenopathy is common, and the disease can present with poor healing, especially of ulcers. Laryngitis can occur with laryngeal TB.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by the formation of granulomas in various tissues, leading to lymphadenopathy, laryngitis, and in some cases, skin ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.reasoning: A bacterial infection that can cause lymphadenopathy in its secondary stage and ulcers (chancre) in its primary stage.

diagnoses.name: Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease that can cause skin ulcers, atherosclerosis, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily affecting joints, this autoimmune disease can also lead to rheumatoid nodules (which may ulcerate), atherosclerosis, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
diagnoses.reasoning: A type of skin cancer that can present as ulcers. Poor healing and lymphadenopathy can occur, especially in advanced stages.

diagnoses.name: Lepromatous Leprosy
diagnoses.reasoning: This form of leprosy can present with skin ulcers, poor healing, lymphadenopathy, and could potentially cause atherosclerosis due to chronic inflammation.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Vitamin deficiency (e.g., Vitamin B12, Vitamin C deficiency)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Eczema (as a manifestation of allergic reaction)
Gastrointestinal disorders causing diarrhea and abdominal swelling
Cardiac failure causing hypoxia and fluid overload symptoms
Chemical exposure causing respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerve fibers, leading to delayed response or permanent nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines that are preceded or accompanied by sensory warning signs or symptoms, such as flashes of light, blind spots, or tingling in your hand or face.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to part of the brain, spinal cord, or retina, which may cause symptoms similar to a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor occurs when abnormal cells form within the brain. The symptoms depend largely on the location of the tumor in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy
diagnoses.description: A rare neurodegenerative disorder that affects your body's involuntary functions, including blood pressure, breathing, bladder function, and motor control.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Inflammation caused by lupus can affect many different body systems.

diagnoses.name: Neuromyelitis Optica
diagnoses.description: Also known as Devic's disease, it is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system that primarily affects the eyes (optic neuritis) and the spinal cord.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the optic nerve, which can cause a sudden reduction in vision and eye pain. It is often associated with multiple sclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder where the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms.

diagnoses: Vasculitis (e.g., Polyarteritis Nodosa, Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Vasculitis (e.g., Polyarteritis Nodosa, Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Epilepsy (as a differential for seizures, not directly causing the other symptoms)
Viral infections (e.g., HIV, COVID-19, particularly in the context of causing lymphopenia and thrombocytopenia)
